```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
train_dockets <- read_csv("~/MUDAC/Data/train_dockets.csv")
test_dockets <- read_csv("~/MUDAC/Data/test_dockets.csv")
districts <- read_csv("~/MUDAC/Data/districts.csv")
train_other_motions<-read_csv("~/MUDAC/Data/test_other_motions.csv")
train_terminating_motions<-read.csv("~/MUDAC/Data/train_terminating_motions.csv")
```

## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r Data Cleaning}
train_dockets <- replace(train_dockets, train_dockets == -8, NA)

train_total_motions <- train_terminating_motions %>% 
  group_by(mudac_id, motion_type) %>% 
  summarise(total_motion=n()) %>% 
  pivot_wider(values_from=total_motion,
              names_from=motion_type)
  
train_dockets %>% 
  mutate(outcome = factor(outcome, levels=c("Settled", "Dismissed", "Summary Judgment", "Verdict","Other")))
  
train_joined <- left_join(train_dockets, train_total_motions)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r Plots}
train_joined %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=outcome)) +
  geom_bar(aes(fill=outcome))

train_joined %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=district)) +
  geom_bar(aes(fill=outcome)) 

train_joined %>% 
  filter(`Motion to Dismiss` >= 1) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=outcome)) +
  geom_bar(aes(fill=outcome)) 

train_joined %>% 
  filter(`Motion for Summary Judgment` >= 1) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=outcome)) +
  geom_bar(aes(fill=outcome)) 
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
